keywords: Caspian terns, double-crested cormorants, banding, resighting, demography, dispersal, Columbia River estuary
abstract:
This text describes a bird banding project carried out on East Sand Island in the Columbia River estuary, focusing on Caspian terns and double-crested cormorants. The purpose of this project is to gather valuable data for evaluating management actions and enhancing our understanding of avian biology and ecology.

The bird banding process involves capturing and banding both adult and juvenile terns and cormorants with field-readable leg bands. These bands serve multiple functions: they help assess survival rates, post-breeding dispersal, movements among colonies, age of first breeding, relative dispersal, and the impact of disturbance or dissuasion on these birds.

The data collected plays a crucial role in determining the effectiveness of management actions aimed at relocating potentially harmful tern and cormorant colonies to protect juvenile salmonids and other fish of conservation concern in the Columbia River estuary. Furthermore, information gathered from this project contributes significantly to our fundamental knowledge of bird behavior and ecology.

Individuals who have encountered banded Caspian terns or double-crested cormorants anywhere in North America can report their sightings via dedicated websites such as www.mybandedtern.org for Caspian terns, and soon an equivalent site for double-crested cormorants. This information is essential for expanding the scope of data collection and enhancing our understanding of these birds' populations and movements.

In summary, bird banding is a critical methodology used in this project to collect necessary data on Caspian terns and double-crested cormorants. It enables the assessment of population dynamics, evaluating management actions, and expanding our knowledge of avian biology and ecology.
description:
This text describes methods employed for banding and resighting Caspian terns and double-crested cormorants at East Sand Island in the Columbia River estuary. These techniques involve capturing and affixing field readable leg bands to adult and juvenile specimens of both bird species (Caspian terns and double-crested cormorants). The data gathered from banding and resighting these birds plays a crucial role in evaluating the effectiveness of management actions to relocate problematic colonies, which may pose a risk to the survival of juvenile salmonids and other fish species of conservation concern.

Demography and dispersal data derived from these banding efforts are essential components of assessing the success of such interventions. This information contributes to understanding avian population dynamics and ecology, as well as the impact of potential disturbances or dissuasions on their populations.

Publicly resighted tern bands can be reported through the dedicated web site www.mybandedtern.org. Similar reporting mechanisms for double-crested cormorants are expected to be established in the near future. For further details about these banding projects and the ensuing data analysis, consult Suzuki (2012).
